Dear Ms. Nichols:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
4/11/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Rori Dodge-Pifer at 517-899-6024.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12202 Policy and procedures.
(1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
procedures for all the areas of foster care services as
provided in R400.12203 to R 400.12214.
The agency requires annual central registry clearances for all its employee. One of
six employees who were employed over a year showed the employee’s 2023 annual
clear clearance due by 12/20/2023 was completed late on 1/2/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12205 Required staff.
(5) An agency shall appoint a social service worker who
possesses at least a bachelor’s degree from an
accredited college or university with a major in a human
behavioral science or in another major where 25% of the
course credits earned toward the degree are in human
behavioral science.
In one of eight new employees records reviewed, the record showed the employee
did not possess a bachelor’s degree. The employee’s transcript showed this person
had more than 25% of her course credits were in human behavior science, but the
degree held is an Ontario, Canada College Advance Diploma for Child and Youth
Worker. The diploma was via a three-year study program.
It is noteworthy the agency did not contact DCWL (Division of Child Welfare
Licensing) about this person’s degree/qualification. The Director advised the agency
2

consulted with the Child Welfare Policy office prior to hiring this person; and after
several email exchanges, were advised on 1/30/2024, that per this person’s
transcript, the degree would suffice. That it appeared this individual had earned 30
semester credits in at least one of the qualifying degrees; specifically Early
Childhood Studies and Psychology.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person
has not been named in a central registry case as the
perpetrator of child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in
any state where the person lived in the 5 years
preceding hire.
In one of eight new employees records reviewed, the record did not show
documentation of a child protective service clearance for this employee who resides
in Ontario, Canada. The agency human resource department was under the
impression the Canadian’s sex offender’s clearance and record’s check sufficed for
this clearance.
The agency recently reported this employee is no longer an employee.
Repeat Violation Established:
2022 Interim CAP approved 8/12/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months
after the staff member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written
evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
Five of 14 employee records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation of an employee probationary
evaluation, which the agency conducts at 90 days. The evaluation due by
2/13/2024 was not documented.
• A second record showed the employee's annual evaluation due by
11/23/2023 was completed late on 2/12/2024.
3

• A third, fourth and fifth record showed the respective employee’s annual
evaluation each due by 11/17/2023 was completed late on, 11/28/ 2023,
3/5/2024 and 3/18/2024 respectively.
CPA Rule 400.12214 Child protection law.
An agency shall comply with the child protection law, 1975
PA 238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
The agency completed local Michigan child protective services (CPS) central registry
clearances for its 8 new employees, but not CPS History Checks via the Division of
Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL) for these new staff, as required.
The agency followed through and submitted the CPS history clearance requests and
received clearance from DCWL for all its new employees by 4/22/2024, just prior to the
writing of this report.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all
the following information:
(c) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children
are interviewed, their last names may not be included in
the report.
One of three special evaluations reviewed did not show how or where all persons
were interviewed, nor showed clarification on how additional contacts and
information from persons was obtained.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(c) Available known information about the child's health.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation that
information required by(c) was provided to the foster parent related to the respective
child's 3/22/2023 and 4/5/2023 placement.

CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child's 4/16/2023-
5/25/2023 initial service plan (ISP) was completed 20 days late on 6/15/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed showed late updated service plans
(USP):
• One child's 4/11/2023-7/9/2023 USP was completed 7 days late on
7/17/2023. This child 7/10/2023-10/7/2023 USP was completed 5 days late
on 10/13/2023.
• A second child's 5/17/2023-8/14/2024 USP was completed 23 days late on
9/7/2023. This child's 11/6/2023-2/4/2024 USP was completed 1 day late on
2/5/2024.
• A third child's 3/24/2023-6/21/2023 USP was completed 63 days late on
8/24/2023.
Repeat Violation Established:
2022 Interim CAP approved 8/12/2022.

(1) The initial service plan, as required in R

CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact.
(4) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between

Two of eight open foster child records reviewed where siblings were split did not

CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record must contain all the following

7

FOM 722 6B Family Team Meeting.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using
the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must
be completed for each type of meeting.
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date. Note: This FTM may be
combined with the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date. Permanent Ward Service
Plan (PWSP) – within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
8

Placement preservation/disruption-At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement or
no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change.
Semi-annual transition meeting- Within 30 calendar days
after the child’s 14th birthday and every six months
thereafter.
Six of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:

• A fifth record did not show documentation of a DHS-1105 for a 10/4/2023 and
1/24/2024 FTM.
• A sixth record did not show documentation of a DHS-1105 for a 5/11/2023
FTM.

2023 Renewal, CAP approved 4/25/2023.
2022 Interim CAP approved 8/12/2022.
FOM 722-8D Treatment Plans.
Agreement and signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
Youth ages 14 and older.
Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the

Three of eight open foster child records reviewed, and one of six open

• One child’s 5/10/2023-8/1/2023 treatment plan was not signed by the birth

• A second child’s 1/3/2023-1/25/2023 treatment plan was not signed by the

• A third child’s 9/16/2023-12/14/2023 treatment plan was not sigend by the

• The independent living youth record showed the youth’s 6/29/2023-
7/28/2023 treatment plan was not signed by the youth until 4/10/2024.

2022 Interim CAP approved 8/12/2022.
FOM 801-C Medical Passport.
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
Four of eight open foster child record reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child's record did not show documentation of a September or December
2023 medical passport.
• A second child's record did not show documentation of a May, August or
November 2023 medical passport.
• A third child’s record did not show documentation of a June medical passport.
• A fourth child's record did not show documentation of a June, September or
December 2023 medical passport.
Repeat Violation Established:
2023 Renewal, CAP approved 4/25/2023.
2022 Interim, CAP approved 8/12/2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
R400.12327(c) Special evaluation.
10

• The agency was apprised a copy of the special evaluation shall
consistently be provided to all workers who had children placed in the
home timely, not weeks or months after the special evaluation closes.
FOM 722-7D Treatment plans.
• The agency was apprised a birth parent, or caregiver’s signature shall not
be dated prior to the supervisor’s approval of the treatment plan.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12326 Borrowed home.
• The agency was advised that listing the child’s date of placement onto the
borrowed bed agreement/agency form, showing that the certifying agency and
foster parent accepts the placement, may aid the agency in showing all
agreements/acceptances occurred prior to the child’s placement.
ADM 330 Quarterly Adoption Progress Report.
• The agency was advised placing the quarterly reporting period timeframe
onto the top of the document, may aid it in showing clearer documentation of
the accurate quarterly reporting period.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted two corrective action plan during this period under
review.
The corrective action plan(CAP) related to its 2023 Renewal inspection completed
on 4/4/2023 where the CAP was approved on 4/25/2023. The agency received 13
violations, 3 of which are repeat violations this year. The agency’s compliance
around these 3 rule violations is as follows: it remained the same in terms of the
number of individual cases related to quarterly adoption progress reports; the
number of individual cases increased from 3 to 6 related to family team meetings;
and increased from 1 individual to 4 cases this year related to medical passports
(all violations were out of 8 cases reviewed both this year and in 2023).
In the agency’s 2022 Interim inspection, 24 violations were established, 7 of which
were repeat violations this year. Repeat violations R400.12212(2)(h) for
11

Personnel records, R400.12418(2)(b)-Development of Service Plans, and FOM
722-8D -Treatment Plans remained the same in terms of the number of individuals
cases cited. R400.12419(1)(c) -Initial Service Plans; and ADM 330-Quarterly
Adoption Progress Reports saw a decrease from 4 individual cases to 1, and 6 to
1 respectively this year. The remaining 2 repeat violations related to individual
incidents of non-compliance saw an increase from 3 to 4 for FOM 801-C-Medical
Passports; and 3 to 6 for 722-6B- Family Team Meeting (both violations were out
of 8 cases reviewed both this year and in 2022). The agency contributes these
violations to worker turnover.
The agency completed various trainings related to the 2023 CAP. They also had
spreadsheets, checklists, reminders, and discussions with staff related to
timeframes. Yet as indicted by the repeat violation not all of the CAP actions/
efforts resulted in increased compliance. The agency will need to develop new
action steps and continue all efforts with staff to enhance rule compliance.
Additionally, the agency will need to work with the human resource department
around CPS history clearance requirements and timeliness.
A second corrective action plan’s approval was pending related to special
investigation 2024SIC0001110, where the agency was cited for R400/12308(1)
pertaining to an allegeation that the agency failed to act on a completed
application for licensure.
Chief Administrator Assessment
I reviewed the agency’s Chief Administrator Assessment report dated 3/4/2024.
The assessment reported the agency has experienced workforce issues in the
form of continued staff turnover, and a high level of less seasoned workers on the
job. Additionally, this is the first year the agency is working with only one program
manager and the agency lost a key support person whose position was created to
help improve compliance. The CA indicated the agency struggled with respect to
key performance indicators (KPI) around medicals and dentals; service plan
completions/approvals; and worker/parent, and parent/child contacts. The CA
reported the agency continues to work to improve all of these areas. To increase
compliance the agency added a health care coordinator, training and supervisor
calendar reminders, workers are encouraged to utilize the BOB (Book of
Business) for report timeframes, and working on assisting birth parent with
transportation so they can participate in parenting times.
The CA reported the corrective action plan has produced positive results overall
as staff are utilizing training, the Department’s/agency’s resources, and utilization
of Microsoft Outlook and the BOB. Additionally, it has held the supervisors
accountable for documentation support to staff and follow up related to tasks.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted a 2023-2024 annual budget, as well as a 9/30/2023 agency
independent financial audit. No major concerns were noted.
12

Staff Interviews
In addition to discussion with the program director, licensee designee, program
manager, three supervisors (licensing, adoption, foster care), a quality assurance
analyst, and two human resource staff during the entrance conference, one foster
care worker, one independent living worker, one licensing worker, and one
adoption worker were interviewed.
The workers reported positives about the agency with respect the agency’s family-
oriented environment, team work amongst it staff; and the communication and
support the agency displays to workers, foster parents, and the foster children and
their families. An area of needed growth reported by workers was for greater staff
retention, increased pay, more structured supervision for some new workers in the
beginning even id that staff comes with past experience. Additionally, for the
agency to have the ability to provide more in house therapy and mental health
treatment for youths over 18.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the facility showed the agency has sufficient space and
equipment. Additionally, case records for each program were securely stored. No
safety issues or concerns were observed.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts.
RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
